CARDINAL . ORG for the GPE of GPE upheld that decision on DATE . It considered that in adopting the criteria set out in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) of ORG of DATE ( see “ Relevant domestic law and practice ” , paragraph CARDINAL below ) ORG ’s intention had not been to generally exempt all people with disabilities from the obligation to pay the tax in question . CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed an administrative complaint with ORG . He claimed , in particular , that he was a victim of discriminatory treatment in so far as , on the one hand , he had been required to pay the exemption tax and , on the other , he had not been allowed to do his military service even though he had always stated his readiness to do it .
CARDINAL . On DATE , when invited by ORG to submit observations on the admissibility and merits of the complaint , the federal tax authorities recommended its rejection .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE , ORG rejected the complaint . Based on the findings of the expert examination of DATE , it held that the applicant did not have a major physical or mental disability within the meaning of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) of ORG . Accordingly , he did not qualify for exemption from the tax . ORG also pointed out that although the medical examination showed that the type of diabetes the applicant had was unlikely to prevent him from holding a normal job , the particular constraints of military service nevertheless obliged the authorities to declare him unfit .

CARDINAL . ORG explained that the aim of the law was to provide a system of compensation between those citizens who did their military service and those who were exempted from it for whatever reason . The tax in issue was meant to replace the effort and inconvenience of military service . As to the complaint of discrimination , the court explained that it was for reasons of equality that the law did not provide for a blanket exemption for all people with disabilities .
CARDINAL . ORG considered that the cantonal authorities had merely correctly applied the law and that it was not the court ’s role to change the law .

CARDINAL . It also held that the fact that the applicant had always declared his willingness to do military service and felt fit to do it as a professional driver did not make any difference , as the law provided for no alternative for someone in his situation but to pay the exemption tax .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW provides the foundation for compulsory military service in GPE . It reads as follows :
Article CARDINAL : Military service and substitute service
“ CARDINAL . All men of NORP nationality shall do military service . The law provides for substitute civilian service .
CARDINAL . NORP women may serve in the army on a voluntary basis .
CARDINAL . All men of NORP nationality who do not do military service or substitute civilian service shall pay a tax . The tax shall be paid to the ORG and fixed and levied by the cantons .

CARDINAL . Under the legislation governing direct federal taxes , the military - service exemption tax is levied on the person ’s total net income . As a result , for a bachelor the income on which the exemption tax is based is the taxable income under the law governing direct federal taxes . The exemption tax is PERCENT of that income ( but MONEY CARDINAL ) . According to the Government that method of calculating the tax has the advantage of sparing the person concerned the trouble of filling in an additional tax declaration for the exemption tax .

CARDINAL ) , ORG decided that in order to determine whether a disability was “ major ” for the purposes of exemption from the tax , what should be taken into consideration were the tables used by ORG in the event of an accident to calculate compensation for bodily harm in accordance with the federal law on accident insurance . The court also considered that the authorities could base their decision on the federal tax authorities’ “ Instructions concerning exoneration from the tax because of a major physical , mental or psychological disability ” , which were based on those tables and could be considered to have the value of a presumption of law in so far as they were sufficiently relevant to the particular case .
CARDINAL . According to the parties there is no “ alternative ” to military service under NORP law .

CARDINAL . Civilian service is a substitute service for people eligible for military service who can not reconcile the obligation to do military service with their conscience . It is regulated by ORG of DATE . The formal condition for eligibility for civilian service is fitness for military service .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of LAW provides separate regulations governing civil protection . The obligation to do civil protection service is unrelated to the obligation to serve in the army , so military service can not be replaced by time spent in the civil protection service . Nor is there any possibility of choosing between military service and civil protection . On the other hand , all the training and work done in civil protection can be taken into account in the calculation of the exemption tax .
